snippet: Economists cited various possible factors behind the addition of only 115,000 jobs in April, but none are likely to comfort 13.7 million jobless workers.
abstract: Labor Department reports that unemployment rate fell to 8.1 percent in April, as employers added only 115,000 jobs; lower rate reflects fact that an estimated 342,000 Americans have dropped out of the job market altogether. Charts, Photo (M)/
lead_paragraph: The nation's employers are creating jobs at less than half the pace they were when this year began, according to a government report released Friday. The addition of just 115,000 jobs in April was disappointing, but economists urged no panic just yet. Maybe the unusually warm winter had encouraged companies to do their spring hiring a little early, they offered in one of several theories. Maybe high gas prices, now falling, temporarily discouraged job growth. Better yet, maybe this latest report understates how many jobs were added, since the initial estimates for earlier months have been revised upward.

headline.main: Rate Of Growth In Jobs Slowed For U.S. In April
